solution_line_template: Melanie set aside {brownies_per_batch} x {bake_sale_fraction} = <<{brownies_per_batch}*{bake_sale_fraction}={bake_sale_brownies_per_batch}>>{bake_sale_brownies_per_batch} brownies from each batch for a bake sale.

So, there are {brownies_per_batch} - {bake_sale_brownies_per_batch} = <<{brownies_per_batch}-{bake_sale_brownies_per_batch}={remaining_brownies_per_batch_after_sale}>>{remaining_brownies_per_batch_after_sale} brownies that are not for bake sale from each batch.

Out of the {remaining_brownies_per_batch_after_sale}, {remaining_brownies_per_batch_after_sale} x {container_fraction} = <<{remaining_brownies_per_batch_after_sale}*{container_fraction}={container_brownies_per_batch}>>{container_brownies_per_batch} brownies are kept in a container from each batch.

Thus, {remaining_brownies_per_batch_after_sale} - {container_brownies_per_batch} = <<{remaining_brownies_per_batch_after_sale}-{container_brownies_per_batch}={given_out_brownies_per_batch}>>{given_out_brownies_per_batch} brownies are given out from each batch.

Therefore, a total of {given_out_brownies_per_batch} x {num_batches} = <<{given_out_brownies_per_batch}*{num_batches}={total_brownies_given_out}>>{total_brownies_given_out} brownies are given out from the {num_batches} batches.
